title: CMS Experience Quiz
description: Test your understanding of content management systems and their architectures.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a traditional CMS and a headless CMS?

options.text: Traditional CMS is free, headless CMS is paid
A headless CMS separates content management from the presentation layer
Traditional CMS uses databases, headless CMS uses files
Headless CMS cannot handle images or media

questions.explanation: A headless CMS decouples the content repository (back end) from the presentation layer (front end), delivering content via APIs. A traditional CMS bundles both together.

questions.question: Which of these is an example of a headless CMS?
questions.explanation: Contentful is a headless CMS that provides content via APIs. WordPress can be used as a headless CMS with its REST API, but its default installation is a traditional CMS.

questions.question: WordPress can only be used as a traditional CMS with server-rendered themes.
questions.explanation: WordPress has a built-in REST API that allows it to function as a headless CMS, serving content to any front-end framework like React, Vue, or Astro.

questions.question: What is 'content modeling' in the context of a CMS?

options.text: Designing the visual layout of content pages
Defining the structure and types of content with fields and relationships

questions.explanation: Content modeling is the process of defining content types, their fields, and relationships. For example, a 'Blog Post' type might have fields for title, body, author (relationship), and tags.

questions.question: When would a headless CMS be a better choice than a traditional CMS?

options.text: When you need a simple blog with no developer involvement
When you need to deliver content to multiple platforms (web, mobile app, kiosk)
When the client needs a WYSIWYG page builder
When you want the cheapest hosting option

questions.explanation: Headless CMS excels when content needs to be consumed by multiple front ends (web, mobile, IoT) because it delivers content via APIs that any platform can consume.
